III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
R400.12509(3)(o) Independent living record:
The agency was advised it shall clearly and consistently show that the youth
signed the treatment plan within the required timeframe.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12212(2)(d) Personnel record:
The agency was advised denoting the name of the person completing the
reference form for an applicant may aid the agency in clearly documenting that
the reference was received rightfully.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan during this
licensing period. The corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2024 Renewal
2

Inspection where it received 8 rule violations; 5 of which were repeat violations.
The agency successfully implemented all aspects of its corrective plan; and made
tremendous progress with its. No rules were cited for this inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
I received and reviewed the agency’s Chief Administrator’s (CA) report dated
8/4/2025. The report indicated with respect to repeat violations related to 30-day
reports, action summaries, and family team meetings, its development of a
standardized form for the former, and training for staff and closer monitoring for
the latter two, seem to have been effective related to rule compliance. The CA
also reported that including the office manager and executive director in the
monitoring procedure had also improved outcomes. Additionally, the corrective
action plan has aided them in gaining clarification around requirements for some
rules and has diffused misinformation, such as related to completion of aspects of
the action summary when a youth AWOLS/leave the agency’s services, but
transfers to another agency.
The agency reported it will continue to work with its staff around compliance with
all rules.
Financial Overview
I received and reviewed a copy of the agency's March 31, 2024, independent
financial audit and 2025 annual budget. No areas of concern were noted from
either document.
Staff Interviews
During the agency’s entrance conference on 8/4/2025 I met with and interviewed
the program manager. I interviewed a foster care worker, youth advocate and life
skill coach by telephone on 8/5/2025. All the staff interviewed felt appreciated
and supported, and that the agency keeps them abreast of changes within the
agency; and related to the agency’s contractors. No areas of concern were
reported. Strengths for the agency were reported as the agency being small and
therefore family-like, and attentive to staff and youths’ needs. The area for growth
reported as needed was also along the lines of the agency being small and therein
not having various resources that larger agencies appreciate, such as the ability to
create TEAMS or ZOOM meetings.
Description of Agency Walk Through
My walk-through of the agency’s facility did not reveal any areas of concern or
safety issues. Personnel and client files were securely stored, and the agency
appeared to have sufficient space and equipment for its staff.
3

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
This agency only provides independent living services. It is not contracted with the
department to provide general foster care and licensing services.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the agency continue on their
regular license.
